title: Quiz 15: Hematology
topicName: NCK Paper 1 Anatomy and Physiology Questions
description: Hematology MCQs covering anemias, coagulation disorders, hematologic malignancies, and interpretation of blood work.

questions.question: A patient presents with fatigue, pallor, and dyspnea on exertion. Laboratory tests reveal a low hemoglobin level, decreased mean corpuscular volume (MCV), and decreased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC). Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: Microcytic (Low MCV) and Hypochromic (Low MCHC) anemia is classic for Iron Deficiency Anemia.
questions.hint: The red blood cells are small and pale.

questions.question: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with bruising, petechiae, and mucosal bleeding. Laboratory tests reveal prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) with decreased platelet count. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: Liver disease can predispose to DIC. The combination of prolonged PT/aPTT (consumption of clotting factors) AND low platelets (consumption of platelets) is characteristic of DIC.
questions.hint: A consumptive coagulopathy involving both factors and platelets.

questions.question: A patient presents with a history of recurrent nosebleeds, easy bruising, and gum bleeding. Laboratory tests reveal prolonged bleeding time and normal platelet count, PT, and aPTT. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: vWD affects platelet adhesion (prolonged bleeding time) but usually leaves platelet count normal. It is the most common inherited bleeding disorder.
questions.hint: A defect in platelet adhesion, not number.

questions.question: A patient presents with fatigue, weakness, and jaundice. Laboratory tests reveal elevated indirect bilirubin levels, reticulocytosis, and positive Coombs test. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: While a positive Coombs test specifically indicates Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia, among the provided choices in this specific past paper context, Hereditary Spherocytosis is the designated hemolytic anemia option, though it is typically Coombs negative.
questions.hint: This condition involves sphere-shaped red blood cells.

questions.question: A patient presents with bone pain, fatigue, and frequent infections. Laboratory tests reveal pancytopenia, hypocellular bone marrow, and absence of reticulocytes. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: Pancytopenia (low RBC, WBC, Platelets) + Hypocellular (empty) marrow = Bone marrow failure, which is the definition of Aplastic Anemia.
questions.hint: The bone marrow has stopped producing all cell lines.

questions.question: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of venous thrombosis, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE), despite no apparent provoking factors. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: Factor V Leiden is the most common hereditary thrombophilia (tendency to clot).
questions.hint: The most common genetic risk factor for DVT.

questions.question: A patient presents with petechiae, purpura, and mucosal bleeding. Laboratory tests reveal thrombocytopenia, elevated serum creatinine, and schistocytes on peripheral blood smear. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: The triad of Thrombocytopenia + Renal Failure (Elevated Creatinine) + Microangiopathic Hemolytic Anemia (Schistocytes) is classic for HUS.
questions.hint: Kidney failure + Low Platelets + Broken RBCs.

questions.question: A patient presents with bone pain, fatigue, and recurrent infections. Laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis with increased blast cells on peripheral blood smear and bone marrow biopsy consistent with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is associated with a favorable prognosis in AML?

options.text: inv(16) or t(16;16) CBFB-MYH11 fusion gene

questions.explanation: t(8;21) is a classic cytogenetic marker associated with a favorable prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia.
questions.hint: Translocation between chromosomes 8 and 21.

questions.question: A patient with a history of chronic kidney disease presents with weakness, anorexia, and confusion. Laboratory tests reveal severe anemia, low reticulocyte count, elevated serum creatinine, and decreased erythropoietin levels. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: The low erythropoietin level is the key. The failing kidneys cannot produce EPO, leading to anemia.
questions.hint: The kidneys make the hormone that tells bone marrow to make RBCs.

questions.question: A patient presents with petechiae, ecchymoses, and gingival bleeding. Laboratory tests reveal prolonged bleeding time, normal platelet count, and normal PT and aPTT. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: Glanzmann's is a platelet function defect (normal count, prolonged bleeding time). Bernard-Soulier typically presents with thrombocytopenia (low count) and giant platelets.
questions.hint: A functional defect of platelets, not a number defect.

questions.question: A patient with a history of Hodgkin lymphoma presents with fever, chills, and generalized malaise. Laboratory tests reveal pancytopenia, circulating Reed-Sternberg cells, and bone marrow involvement. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: The presence of pancytopenia and marrow involvement in a patient with history of lymphoma treatment suggests secondary Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS) or leukemia.
questions.hint: A secondary malignancy often caused by previous chemotherapy/radiation.

questions.question: A patient presents with severe headache, blurred vision, and fatigue. Laboratory tests reveal elevated white blood cell count, thrombocytosis, and presence of JAK2 V617F mutation. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: Thrombocytosis (high platelets) + JAK2 mutation is characteristic of Essential Thrombocythemia.
questions.hint: The name implies 'essential' high platelets.

questions.question: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with easy bruising and prolonged bleeding from minor cuts. Laboratory tests reveal prolonged PT and aPTT, and mixing studies show correction of coagulation times with normal plasma. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: Liver disease leads to decreased production of coagulation factors (prolonging PT/aPTT). Correction with mixing study confirms factor deficiency (not an inhibitor).
questions.hint: The liver produces most clotting factors.

questions.question: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of antiphospholipid antibodies (anticardiolipin and lupus anticoagulant). Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: The presence of antiphospholipid antibodies + thrombosis defines Antiphospholipid Syndrome.
questions.hint: An acquired autoimmune thrombophilia.

questions.question: A patient with a history of sickle cell disease presents with severe abdominal pain, fever, and jaundice. Laboratory tests reveal anemia, reticulocytosis, elevated indirect bilirubin, and presence of Howell-Jolly bodies on peripheral blood smear. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: The constellation of jaundice, reticulocytosis (marrow trying to compensate), and high bilirubin suggests acute hemolysis (Hemolytic crisis). Howell-Jolly bodies indicate functional asplenia.
questions.hint: Accelerated destruction of RBCs causes jaundice.

questions.question: A patient presents with pallor, fatigue, and exertional dyspnea. Laboratory tests reveal a low hemoglobin level, low MCV, and elevated red blood cell distribution width (RDW). Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: High RDW (variation in cell size) is a key differentiator for Iron Deficiency Anemia vs Thalassemia (which usually has normal RDW).
questions.hint: Cells of varying sizes (anisocytosis) are common in this nutrient deficiency.

questions.question: A patient with a history of multiple myeloma presents with weakness, bone pain, and recurrent infections. Laboratory tests reveal anemia, hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency, and monoclonal spike on serum protein electrophoresis. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: The classic 'CRAB' symptoms: Calcium elevation, Renal insufficiency, Anemia, Bone lesions are hallmarks of Multiple Myeloma.
questions.hint: CRAB symptoms.

questions.question: A patient presents with abdominal pain, fever, and peripheral blood smear showing fragmented red blood cells (schistocytes). Laboratory tests reveal elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), decreased haptoglobin, and increased indirect bilirubin. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: TTP is a microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (schistocytes, low haptoglobin) often presenting with fever and neuro/abdominal symptoms.
questions.hint: A medical emergency treated with plasma exchange.

questions.question: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with ecchymoses, mucosal bleeding, and altered mental status. Laboratory tests reveal prolonged PT and aPTT, low fibrinogen levels, and elevated D-dimer. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: While liver disease causes coagulopathy, the specific finding of *low fibrinogen* and *elevated D-dimer* strongly suggests superimposed DIC.
questions.hint: Widespread clotting followed by bleeding.

questions.question: A patient presents with fatigue, weakness, and jaundice. Laboratory tests reveal hemolytic anemia, elevated LDH, decreased haptoglobin, and presence of schistocytes on peripheral blood smear. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: AIHA fits the general hemolytic picture described in the options provided for this specific question context.
questions.hint: Immune destruction of RBCs.

questions.question: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of epistaxis, gum bleeding, and easy bruising. Laboratory tests reveal prolonged bleeding time, normal platelet count, and normal PT and aPTT. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: vWD is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, affecting platelet function (bleeding time) without necessarily lowering the count.
questions.hint: Deficiency of a factor that helps platelets stick.

questions.question: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of joint pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in multiple joints. Laboratory tests reveal elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), positive rheumatoid factor (RF), and presence of anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: Anti-CCP is highly specific for Rheumatoid Arthritis.
questions.hint: Chronic autoimmune joint inflammation.

questions.question: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of fever, sore throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis with atypical lymphocytes on peripheral blood smear and positive heterophile antibody test (Monospot test). Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: Positive Monospot + Atypical Lymphocytes = EBV Infectious Mononucleosis.
questions.hint: The 'Kissing Disease'.

questions.question: A patient presents with fatigue, pallor, and exertional dyspnea. Laboratory tests reveal severe anemia, low serum iron, low transferrin saturation, and elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC). Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: High TIBC (transferrin trying to find iron) with low serum iron is diagnostic of Iron Deficiency.
questions.hint: The body is hungry for iron, so binding capacity goes up.

questions.question: A patient presents with generalized weakness, headache, and difficulty concentrating. Laboratory tests reveal normocytic normochromic anemia, normal iron studies, and elevated serum erythropoietin levels. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause these findings?
questions.explanation: If EPO is high but the marrow isn't responding (anemia persists), and iron is normal, it suggests marrow failure (Aplastic Anemia). CKD would have low EPO.
questions.hint: The signal (EPO) is high, but the factory (marrow) isn't working.
